title: CS506: Data Wrangling and Management
text:
Preface
Welcome to CS506: Data Wrangling and Management. This course introduces graduate students to data wrangling and management using R and the Tidyverse ecosystem. Students will learn to import, manipulate, clean, and visualize data with a strong emphasis on practical applications and reproducible workflows. The course will utilize the free textbook R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham and Garrett Grolemund.
Course Objectives: Upon successful completion of the course, students will be able to:
Textbook: R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund (Available for free: https://r4ds.hadley.nz/)
Software Requirements:

title: CS506: Data Wrangling and Management
text:
Footnotes

This is a Quarto book. To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.
This website is published using Github Pages.

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
2.1 Learning Objectives
By the end of this chapter, you should be able to:
R is a programming language designed for data analysis.RStudio is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) that makes working with R easier.
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
Install and open R and RStudio

Navigate the four-pane layout of RStudio

Create and run R scripts

Understand the differences between the console, script editor, and environment

Execute basic R operations and understand data types

Install and load R packages
## Getting Started



2.1.1 Installing R and RStudio

Install R: https://cran.r-project.org/

Install RStudio: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/


Once you open RStudio, you’ll see four panes:


Console – for running code interactively


Source – to write and save scripts


Environment/History – to view and manage objects


Files/Plots/Packages/Help/Viewer – navigation and visualization tools
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
2.2 Key Concepts

RStudio panes: Source, Console, Environment, Files

Script vs interactive console

Basic data types (numeric, character, logical) and vectors

Using dput() for reproducible sharing (R4DS Intro) :contentReferenceoaicite:1
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Appendix A: Course Syllabus

A.4 Practice Exercises

Describe the task
Load and analyze a dataset

title: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
2.2 Basic R Concepts

2.2.1 Variables and Assignments

x <- 5
y <- 10
z <- x + y
z

[1] 15



2.2.2 Vectors and Functions

ages <- c(25, 30, 35, 40)
mean(ages)

[1] 32.5

sd(ages)

[1] 6.454972



2.2.3 Data Frames

name <- c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie")
age <- c(25, 30, 35)
student_data <- data.frame(name, age)
student_data

     name age
1   Alice  25
2     Bob  30
3 Charlie  35



2.2.4 Inspecting Data

str(student_data)

'data.frame':   3 obs. of  2 variables:
 $ name: chr  "Alice" "Bob" "Charlie"
 $ age : num  25 30 35

summary(student_data)

     name                age      
 Length:3           Min.   :25.0  
 Class :character   1st Qu.:27.5  
 Mode  :character   Median :30.0  
                    Mean   :30.0  
                    3rd Qu.:32.5  
                    Max.   :35.0  

head(student_data)

     name age
1   Alice  25
2     Bob  30
3 Charlie  35



2.2.5 Comments and Help

# This is a comment
?mean  # Help for the mean function


2.2.6 Using Scripts and Console

Write your code in the script editor and run lines with Ctrl+Enter (Cmd+Enter on Mac)
Save your work with .R extensions
Use the Console for quick exploration

2.2.7 Insalling and Loading Packages
#Run this manually in the Console, not in the book install.packages(“tidyverse”)

2.2.8 Practice Exercises

Create a script that assigns two numbers and prints their sum
Create a vector of Celsius temperatures and convert to Fahrenheit
Create a data frame with columns: name, age, major


# Exercise 1
a <- 15
b <- 20
a + b

[1] 35

# Exercise 2
celsius <- c(0, 10, 20)
fahrenheit <- celsius * 9/5 + 32
fahrenheit

[1] 32 50 68

# Exercise 3
students <- data.frame(
  name = c("Lily", "Mark", "Tom"),
  age = c(21, 22, 23),
  major = c("Biology", "Math", "History")
)
str(students)

'data.frame':   3 obs. of  3 variables:
 $ name : chr  "Lily" "Mark" "Tom"
 $ age  : num  21 22 23
 $ major: chr  "Biology" "Math" "History"



2.2.9 Next Steps
Now that you can run R scripts and explore objects, you’ll learn how to load and reshape real data using the tidyverse in the next chapter.
crumbs: 2  Introduction to R and RStudio
